question: Question 1 The general form of the complementary function of a differential equation is given by [latex]y(t)=(A t+B) e^{-2 t}[/latex], where [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] are real constants determined by the initial condition. The corresponding differential equation is
solution:
[latex]\because[/latex] Given Complementary function [latex]=(A t+B) e^{-2 t} \approx\left(C_{1}+C_{2} t\right) e^{-2 t}[/latex] i.e. roots of auxiliary equation are [latex]m=-2,-2[/latex] So, [latex]\mathrm{AE}[/latex] is [latex](m+2)(m+2)=0[/latex] [latex]
m^{2}+4 m+4=0
[/latex] Replace [latex]m \rightarrow D[/latex] we get, [latex]
\left(D^{2}+4 D+4\right) y=0
[/latex] i.e. the required different [latex]
\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}+4 \frac{d y}{d x}+4 y=f(t)
[/latex]

question: Question 2 In the context of Bode magnitude plots, [latex]40 \mathrm{~dB} /[/latex] decade is the same as _______

Question 3 In the feedback control system shown in the figure below [latex]G(s)=\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex]. [latex]R(s), Y(s)[/latex], and [latex]E(s)[/latex] are the Laplace transforms of [latex]r(t), y(t)[/latex], and [latex]e(t)[/latex], respectively. If the input [latex]r(t)[/latex] is a unit step function, then _____
solution:
Given system is [latex]
G(s)=\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)}
[/latex] The characteristic equation, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
1+G(s) & =0 \\
1+\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)} & =0 \\
s(s+1)(s+2)+6 & =0 \\
s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+6 & =0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Clearly, here the internal coefficient product is equal to external coefficient product i.e., [latex]
3 \times 2=6 \times 1
[/latex] Hence, the given system is marginally stable system. [latex]\therefore e(t)[/latex] not exist because system is oscillatory system.

options.D: [latex]\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} e(t)[/latex] does not exist, [latex]e(t)[/latex] is oscillatory

question: Question 4 A digital communication system transmits through a noiseless bandlimited channel [latex][-W W][/latex]. The received signal [latex]z(t)[/latex] at the output of the receiving filter is given by [latex]z(t)=\sum_{n} b[n] x(t-n T)[/latex] where [latex]b[n][/latex] are the symbols and [latex]x(t)[/latex] is the overall system response to a single symbol. The received signal is sampled at [latex]t=m T[/latex]. The Fourier transform of [latex]x(t)[/latex] is [latex]X(f)[/latex]. The Nyquist condition that [latex]X(f)[/latex] must satisfy for zero intersymbol interference at the receiver is ______
solution:
For zero ISI, [latex]x(t)[/latex] should have zero crossings at [latex]\pm T, \pm 2 T, \pm 3 T \ldots[/latex] [latex]x(t) \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t-m T)=x(0) \delta(t)[/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{T} \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} x\left(f-\frac{m}{T}\right)=x(0)[/latex] [latex]
\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} X\left(f-\frac{m}{T}\right)=x(0) T
[/latex] (or) [latex]
\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} X\left(f+\frac{m}{T}\right)=x(0) T
[/latex] As per GATE official Answer Key-MTA

question: Question 5 Consider a lossless transmission line terminated with a short circuit as shown in the figure below. As one moves towards the generator from the load, the normalized impedances [latex]z_{\text {in } A}, z_{\text {in } B}, z_{\text {in } C}[/latex] and [latex]z_{\text {in } D}[/latex] (indicated in the figure) are _____
solution:
[latex]Z_{s / c}=j Z_{0} \tan \beta l[/latex]. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Normalized impedance, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{Z}_{S / C}=\frac{Z_{S / C}}{Z_{0}}=j \tan \beta l \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } A}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{8}\right)=j \tan (\pi / 4)=j 1 \Omega \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } B}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{4}\right)=\infty \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } C}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{3 \lambda}{8}\right)=-j 1 \Omega \\
& \bar{Z}_{\text {in } D}=j \tan \left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

options.A: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=+0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=\infty, z_{\text {in } C}=-0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=0[/latex]
options.B: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=\infty, z_{\text {in } B}=+0.4 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } C}=0, z_{\text {in } D}=+0.4 j \Omega[/latex]
options.C: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=-1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=0, z_{\text {in } C}=+1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=\infty[/latex]
options.D: [latex]z_{\text {in } A}=+1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } B}=\infty, z_{\text {in } C}=-1 j \Omega, z_{\text {in } D}=0[/latex]

question: Question 6 Let [latex]\hat{i}[/latex] and [latex]\hat{j}[/latex] be the unit vectors along [latex]x[/latex] and [latex]y[/latex] axes, respectively and let [latex]A[/latex] be a positive constant. Which one of the following statements is true for the vector fields [latex]\vec{F}_{1}=A(\hat{i} y+\hat{j} x)[/latex] and [latex]\vec{F}_{2}=A(\hat{i} y-\hat{j} x) ?[/latex]
solution:
For an electrostatic field, [latex]\nabla \times \bar{F}=0[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{F}_{1}=A[y \hat{i}+x \hat{j}] \\
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Delta \times \bar{F}_{1}=A\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\
\partial / \partial x & \partial / \partial y & \partial / \partial z \\
y & x & 0
\end{array}\right| \\
& =A[0 \hat{i}-0 \hat{j}+(1-1) \hat{k}] \\
& =0 \\
& \bar{F}_{2}=A[y \hat{i}-x \hat{j}] \\
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Delta \times \bar{F}_{2}=A\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\
\partial / \partial x & \partial / \partial y & \partial / \partial z \\
y & -x & 0
\end{array}\right| \\
& =A[0 \hat{i}-0 \hat{j}+(-1-1) \hat{k}] \\
& =-2 A \hat{k}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Hence, [latex]\bar{F}_{1}[/latex] is electrostatic, [latex]\bar{F}_{2}[/latex] is not electrostatic.

options.D: Neither [latex]\vec{F}_{1}[/latex] nor [latex]\vec{F}_{2}[/latex] is an electrostatic field.

question: Question 7 In the circuit below, assume that the long channel NMOS transistor is biased in saturation. The small signal trans-conductance of the transistor is [latex]g_{m}[/latex] Neglect body effect, channel length modulation and intrinsic device capacitances. The small signal input impedance [latex]Z_{\text {in }}(j \omega)[/latex] is _____
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& I_{i}=\frac{V_{i}-V_{0}}{z_{i}}=\frac{V_{i}}{z_{i}}-\frac{V_{0}}{z_{i}} \\
& V_{0}=\left(I_{i}+g_{m} V_{g s}\right) z_{L} \\
& V_{0}=I_{i} Z_{L}+g_{m} V_{g S} z_{L} \\
& V_{0}=I_{i}\left(z_{L}+g_{m} z_{1} z_{L}\right) \\
& I_{i}=\frac{V_{1}^{i}}{z_{1}}-\frac{I_{i}\left(z_{L}+g_{m} z_{1} z_{L}\right)}{z_{1}} \\
& I_{i} \frac{\left[z_{1}+z_{L}+g_{m} z_{1} z_{L}\right]}{z_{1}}=\frac{V_{L}^{i}}{z_{1}} \\
& \frac{V_{L}^{i}}{I_{i}}=z_{1}+z_{L}+g_{m} z_{1} z_{L} \\
& z_{\text {in }}=\frac{1}{j \omega C_{1}}+\frac{1}{j \omega C_{L}}-\frac{g_{m}}{\omega^{2} C_{1} C_{L}}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 8 For the closed loop amplifier circuit shown below, the magnitude of open loop low frequency small signal voltage gain is 40. All the transistors are biased in saturation. The current source Iss is ideal. Neglect body effect. channel length modulation and intrinsic device capacitances. The closed loop low frequency small signal voltage gain [latex]\frac{V_{\text {out }}}{V_{\text {in }}}[/latex] (rounded off to three decimal places) is ____.
solution:
[latex]
A_{O L}=40
[/latex] Given circuit is differential amplifier with current mirror active load. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
V_{f} & =V_{\text {out }} \\
\frac{V_{f}}{V_{\text {out }}} & =\beta=1 \\
A_{C L} & =\frac{A_{O L}}{1+\beta A_{O L}}=\frac{40}{1+1 \times 40} \\
A_{C L} & =0.976
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:

F(A, B, C, D)=\Sigma m(0,2,5,7,8,10,12,13,14,15)
[/latex] the essential prime implicants are
solution:
[latex]
f(A, B, C, D)=\Sigma m(0.2,5,7,8,10,12,13,14,15)
[/latex] [latex]B D \quad \bar{B} \bar{D}[/latex]

question: Question 10 A White Gaussian noise [latex]w(t)[/latex] with zero mean and power spectral density [latex]\frac{N_{0}}{2}[/latex], when applied to a first-order [latex]R C[/latex] low pass filter produces an output [latex]n(t)[/latex]. At a particular time [latex]t=t_{k}[/latex], the variance of the random variable [latex]n\left(t_{k}\right)[/latex] is _____

Question 11 A causal and stable LTI system with impulse response [latex]h(t)[/latex] produces an output [latex]y(t)[/latex] for an input signal [latex]x(t)[/latex]. A signal [latex]x(0.5 t)[/latex] is applied to another causal and stable LTI system with impulse response [latex]h(0.5 t)[/latex]. The resulting output is ______
solution:
[latex]
y(t)=x(t) * h(t)
[/latex] [latex]x(t) \leftrightarrow X(\omega)[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
x(0.5 t) & \leftrightarrow 2 X(2 \omega) \\
h(0.5 t) & \leftrightarrow 2 H(2 \omega) \\
y(t) & \leftrightarrow Y(\omega) \\
Y(\omega) & \leftrightarrow X(\omega) \times H(\omega)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] After scaling, [latex]
Y_{1}(\omega)=2 X(2 \omega) \times 2 H(2 \omega)
[/latex] [latex]
=4 X(2 \omega) \times H(2 \omega)
[/latex] After taking inverser Fourier transform [latex]
y_{1}(t)=2 y(0.5 t)
[/latex]

question: Question 12 For non-degenerately doped n-type silicon, which one of the following plots represents the temperature [latex](T)[/latex] dependence of free electron concentration [latex](n)[/latex] ?

Question 13 In the circuit shown, the [latex]n: 1[/latex]  step-down transformer and the diodes are ideal. The diodes have no voltage drop in forward biased condition. If the input voltage (in Volts) is [latex]V_{s}(t)=10 \sin \omega t[/latex] and the average value of load voltage [latex]V_{L}(t)[/latex] (in Volts) is [latex]2.5 / \pi[/latex], the value of [latex]n[/latex] is ______
solution:
Given, [latex]
V_{D C}=\frac{2 V_{M}}{\pi}=\frac{2.5}{\pi}
[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
V_{M} & =\frac{2.5}{2} \\
\therefore \quad 2 V_{M} & =V_{S}=2.5 \mathrm{~V} \\
n: 1 & =\frac{V_{P}}{V_{s}}: 1 \\
& =\frac{10}{2.5}: 1 \\
& =4: 1
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \quad n=4
[/latex]

Given: [latex]H(z)=\frac{2 z^{2}+3}{\left(z+\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(z-\frac{1}{3}\right)}[/latex] System is non-minimum phase system. Since zero are lying outside the unit circle. Final value: [latex]
h(\infty)=\lim _{z \rightarrow 1}(z-1) \frac{2 z^{2}+3}{\left(z+\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(z-\frac{1}{3}\right)}=0
[/latex] Initial value: [latex]
\begin{aligned}
h(0) & =\lim _{z \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(2 z^{2}+3\right)}{\left(z+\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(z-\frac{1}{3}\right)}=\lim _{z \rightarrow \infty} \frac{z^{2}\left[2+\frac{3}{z^{2}}\right]}{z^{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{3 z}\right]\left[1-\frac{1}{3 z}\right]} \\
& =\lim _{z \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left[2+\frac{3}{z^{2}}\right]}{\left[1+\frac{1}{3 z}\right]\left[1-\frac{1}{3 z}\right]}=\frac{2}{1 \times 1}=2 \\
|z| & =\frac{1}{3}=0.33
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]z=-\frac{1}{3}, z=\frac{1}{3}[/latex] System is stable. Since [latex]\mid[/latex] pole [latex]\mid \lt 1[/latex] i.e. pole are lying inside the unit circle.

options.B: The system is a minimum phase system.
options.C: The initial value of the impulse response is 2.
options.D: The final value of the impulse response is 0.

question: Question 15 Let [latex]\rho(x, y, z, t)[/latex] and [latex]u(x, y, z, t)[/latex] represent density and velocity, respectively, at a point [latex](x, y, z)[/latex] and time [latex]t[/latex]. Assume [latex]\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}[/latex] is continuous. Let [latex]V[/latex] be an arbitrary volume in space enclosed by the closed surface [latex]S[/latex] and [latex]\hat{n}[/latex] be the outward unit normal of [latex]S[/latex]. Which of the following equations is/are equivalent [latex]\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot(\rho u)=0[/latex] ?

options.A: [latex]\int_{V} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} d v=-\oint_{S} \rho u \cdot \hat{n} d s[/latex]
options.B: [latex]\int_{V} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} d v=\oint_{S} \rho u \cdot \hat{n} d s[/latex]
options.C: [latex]\int_{V} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} d v=-\int_{V} \nabla \cdot(\rho u) d v[/latex]
options.D: [latex]\int_{V} \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} d v=\int_{V} \nabla \cdot(\rho u) d v[/latex]

question: Question 16 The free electron concentration profile [latex]n(x)[/latex] in a doped semiconductor at equilibrium is shown in the figure, where the points [latex]A, B[/latex], and [latex]C[/latex] mark three different positions. Which of the following statements is/are true?

options.A: For [latex]x[/latex] between [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{C}[/latex], the electron diffusion current is directed from [latex]\mathrm{C}[/latex] to [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex].
options.B: For [latex]x[/latex] between [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{A}[/latex], the electron drift current is directed from [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] to [latex]\mathrm{A}[/latex].
options.C: For [latex]x[/latex] between [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{C}[/latex], the electric field is directed from [latex]\mathrm{B}[/latex] to [latex]\mathrm{C}[/latex].
options.D: For [latex]x[/latex] between [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]A[/latex]. the electric field is directed from [latex]A[/latex] to [latex]B[/latex].

question: Question 17 A machine has a 32-bit architecture with 1-word long instructions. It has 24 registers and supports an instruction set of size 40. Each instruction has five distinct fields, namely opcode, two source register identifiers, one destination register identifier, and an immediate value. Assuming that the immediate operand is an unsigned integer, its maximum value is ______.
solution:
Given 32-bit architecture [latex]\{1[/latex] word long instructions [latex]\}[/latex] [latex]
1 \text { word }=32 \text {-bits }
[/latex] Number of registers [latex]=24[/latex], bits required [latex]\Rightarrow 2^{n}=24[/latex] [latex]
n=\log _{2}(24)
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \quad n=5 \text {-bits }
[/latex] Number instructions [latex]=40[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Opcode bits would be [latex]2^{n}=40[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad n=\log _{2}(40)[/latex] [latex]
n=6 \text {-bits }
[/latex] Each register field requires 5 -bits. Instruction format would be [latex]\therefore[/latex] Immediate value bits [latex]=32-(6+5+5+5)=32-21=11[/latex]-bits The range of unsigned values [latex]=0[/latex] to [latex]2^{n}-1[/latex] [latex]
=0 \text { to } 2^{11}-1=0 \text { to }(2048-1)=0 \text { to } 2047
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Maximum unsigned integer [latex]=2047[/latex]

question:
Question 18 An amplitude modulator has output (in Volts) [latex]
s(t)=A \cos (400 \pi t)+B \cos (360 \pi t)+B \cos (440 \pi t)
[/latex] The carrier power normalized to [latex]1 \Omega[/latex] resistance is 50 Watts. The ratio of the total sideband power to the total power is [latex]1 / 9[/latex]. The value of [latex]B[/latex] (in Volts. rounded off to two decimal places) is ______
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{C} & =\frac{A^{2}}{2}=50 \\
A & =10 \\
\frac{P_{S B}}{P_{t}} & =\frac{\mu^{2}}{2+\mu^{2}}=\frac{1}{9} \\
\mu & =\frac{1}{2} \\
B & =\frac{A_{c} \mu}{2}=\frac{10}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=2.5
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 19 In a number system of base [latex]r[/latex], the equation [latex]x^{2}-12 x+37=0[/latex] has [latex]x=8[/latex] as one of its solutions. The value of [latex]r[/latex] is ______

solution:
[latex]\because[/latex] Given vectors form basis so there must be L.I and its condition is, [latex]
|A| \neq 0
[/latex] or [latex]
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 3 & 1 \\
-3 & -1 & -5 \\
a & 3 & 7
\end{array}\right| \neq 0
[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
2[-7+15]-3[-21+5 a]+1[-9+a] & \neq 0 \\
16+63-15 a-9+a & \neq 0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad-14 a & \neq-70 \\
\Rightarrow & a \neq 5
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 21 In the given circuit, the current [latex]I_{x}[/latex] (in [latex]\mathrm{mA}[/latex] ) is _____

Question 22 In the circuit given below, the switch S was kept open for a sufficiently long time and is closed at time [latex]t=0[/latex]. The time constant (in seconds) of the circuit for [latex]t > 0[/latex] is ______
solution: After the switch closed For time constant, current source is open circuit.

question: Question 23 Suppose [latex]X[/latex] and [latex]Y[/latex] are independent and identically distributed random variables that are distributed uniformly in the interval [latex][0,1][/latex]. The probability that [latex]X \geq Y[/latex] is ______
solution:
Let [latex]
P(X \geq Y)=P(X-Y \geq 0)
[/latex] [latex]
Z=X+(-Y)
[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
&P(Z \geq 0)=\int_0^{\infty} f_z(Z) d_z\\
&f_z(z)=f_x(z) \text { * } f_{-y}(z)
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]P(Z \geq 0)=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 24 A source transmits symbols from an alphabet of size 16. The value of maximum achievable entropy (in bits) is ______
solution:
[latex]
H_{\text {max }}=\log _{2} 16=4
[/latex]

question: Question 25 As shown in the circuit, the initial voltage across the capacitor is [latex]10 \mathrm{~V}[/latex], with the switch being open. The switch is then closed at [latex]t=0[/latex]. The total energy dissipated in the ideal Zener diode ( [latex]V_{z}=5 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] ) after the switch is closed (in [latex]\mathrm{mJ}[/latex], rounded off to three decimal places) is ________

Question 26 Consider the Earth to be a perfect sphere of radius [latex]R[/latex]. Then the surface area of the region, enclosed by the [latex]60^{\circ} \mathrm{N}[/latex] latitude circle, that contains the north pole in its interior is _______

Question 27 Consider a unity negative feedback control system with forward path gain [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex] as shown.
The impulse response of the closed-loop system decays faster than [latex]e^{-t}[/latex] if ______
solution:
Given, [latex]
G(s)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)}
[/latex] Impulse response of system is [latex]
Y(S)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)+K}
[/latex] Given: At impulse response of closed loop system decay faster than [latex]e^{-t}[/latex] Hence, put [latex]s=s-1[/latex], [latex]\therefore[/latex] The new characteristic equation is, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& (s-1+1)(s-1+2)(s-1+3)+K=0 \\
& s(s+1)(s+2)+K=0 \\
& s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+K=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] By [latex]\mathrm{RH}[/latex] criterion, [latex]
\begin{array}{c|cc}
s^{3} & 1 & 2 \\
s^{2} & 3 & K \\
s^{1} & \frac{6-K}{3} & \\
s^{0} & K &
\end{array}
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore K \gt 0 ; \quad \frac{6-K}{3} \gt 0 \Rightarrow K \lt 6
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \quad 0 \lt K \lt 6
[/latex] Hence, option satisfies above range of [latex]K[/latex].

question: Question 28 A satellite attitude control system, as shown below, has a plant with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}}[/latex] cascaded with a compensator [latex]C(s)=\frac{K(s+\alpha)}{s+4}[/latex], where [latex]K[/latex] and [latex]\alpha[/latex] are positive real constants. In order for the closed-loop system to have poles at [latex]-1 \pm j \sqrt{3}[/latex], the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] must be ____
solution:
[latex]
G(S) C(s)=\frac{1}{S^{2}} \frac{k(S+\alpha)}{(S+4)}
[/latex] Characteristic equation is [latex]
S^{3}+4 S^{2}+k S+\alpha=0
[/latex] Poles of the system present at [latex]=-1 \pm j \sqrt{3}[/latex] Characteristic equation is [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&(S+a)\left[(S+1)^{2}+3\right]=0 \\
&(S+a)\left(S^{2}+2 S+4\right)=0 \\
& S^{3}+(2+a) S^{2}+(4+2 a) S+4 a=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Compare equation (I) and (II) [latex]
\begin{aligned}
2+a & =4 \\
a & =2 \\
4+2 a & =k \\
k & =8 \\
k \alpha & =4 a \\
\alpha & =\frac{8}{8}=1 \\
\alpha & =1
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 29 A uniform plane wave with electric field [latex]\vec{E}(x)=A_{y} \hat{a}_{y} e^{-j \frac{2 \pi x}{3}} \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] is travelling in the air (relative permittivity, [latex]\epsilon_{r}=1[/latex] and relative permeability, [latex]\mu_{r}=1[/latex] ) in the [latex]+x[/latex] direction [latex]\left(A_{y}\right.[/latex] is a positive constant, [latex]\hat{a}_{y}[/latex] is the unit vector along the [latex]y[/latex] axis). It is incident normally on an ideal electric conductor (conductivity, [latex]\sigma=\infty[/latex] ) at [latex]x=0[/latex]. The position of the first null of the total magnetic field in the air (measured from [latex]x=0[/latex], in metres) is ________

Question 30 A 4-bit priority encoder has inputs [latex]D_{3}, D_{2}, D_{1}[/latex] and [latex]D_{0}[/latex] in descending order of priority. The two-bit output [latex]A B[/latex] is generated as 00,01, 10, and 11 corresponding to inputs [latex]D_{3}[/latex], [latex]D_{2}, D_{1}[/latex] and [latex]D_{0}[/latex], respectively. The Boolean expression of the output bit [latex]B[/latex] is _____
solution:
Given 4-bit priority encoder has inputs [latex]D_{3}, D_{2}, D_{1}[/latex] and [latex]D_{0}[/latex] in descending order of priority. [latex]
\begin{array}{|cccc|c|c|}
\hline
D_{3} & D_{2} & D_{1} & D_{0} & A & B \\
\hline
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & X & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & X & X & 1 & 0 \\
1 & X & X & X & 1 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex] The Boolean expression of the output bit [latex]B=\overline{D_{3}} D_{2}+\overline{D_{3}} \; \overline{D_{1}}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The propagation delay of the [latex]2 \times 1 \mathrm{MUX}[/latex] shown in the circuit is [latex]10 \mathrm{~ns}[/latex]. Consider the propagation delay of the inverter as [latex]0 \mathrm{~ns}[/latex]. If [latex]S[/latex] is set to 1 then the output [latex]Y[/latex] is ______
Question 32 The sequence of states [latex]\left(Q_{1} Q_{0}\right)[/latex] of the given synchronous sequential circuit is ______

Question 33 Let [latex]z[/latex] be a complex variable. If [latex]f(z)=\frac{\sin (\pi z)}{z^{2}(z-2)}[/latex] and [latex]C[/latex] is the circle in the complex plane with [latex]|z|=3[/latex] then [latex]\oint_{c} f(z) d z[/latex] is ______

Question 34 Consider two continuous time signals [latex]x(t)[/latex] and [latex]y(t)[/latex] as shown below If [latex]X(f)[/latex] denotes the Fourier transform of [latex]x(t)[/latex], then the Fourier transform of [latex]y(t)[/latex] is ____

Question 35 A source transmits a symbol [latex]s[/latex], taken from [latex](-4,0,4)[/latex] with equal probability, over an additive white Gaussian noise channel. The received noisy symbol [latex]r[/latex] is given by [latex]r=s+w[/latex], where the noise [latex]w[/latex] is zero mean with variance 4 and is independent of [latex]s[/latex]. Using [latex]Q(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{x}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-t^{2}}{2}} d t[/latex], the optimum symbol error probability is ______
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
r & =s+\omega \\
f_{\omega}(\omega) & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{\frac{-\omega^{2}}{2 \times 4}}=N(0,4)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] transmission of [latex]-4 \rightarrow r=-4+\omega[/latex] [latex]
f(r /-4)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{\frac{-(r+4)^{2}}{2 \times 4}}
[/latex] transmission of [latex]0 \rightarrow r=\omega[/latex] [latex]
f(r / 0)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-\frac{r^{2}}{2 \times 4}}
[/latex] transmission of [latex]4 \rightarrow r=4+n[/latex] [latex]
f(r / 4)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{\frac{-(r-4)^{2}}{2 \times 4}}
[/latex] [latex]
P_{e}=P(-4) P_{e-4}+P(0) P_{e 0}+P(4) P_{e 4}
[/latex] Given [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& P(-4)=P(0)=P(4)=\frac{1}{3} \\
& P_{e-4}=P(r \gt -2) \\
& =1-\left(1-F_{r}(2)\right) \\
& =1-\left(1-Q\left(\frac{-2+4}{2}\right)\right) \\
& =Q(1) \\
& P_{e 0}=P(r \lt -2)+P(r \gt 2) \\
& =F_{r}(-2)+\left\{1-F_{r}(2)\right\} \\
& =\left(1-Q\left(\frac{-2-0}{2}\right)\right)+Q\left(\frac{2-0}{2}\right) \\
& =[1-Q(-1)]+Q(1)=2 Q(1)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{e 4} & =P(r \lt 2) \\
& =F_{r}(2) \\
& =1-Q\left(\frac{2-4}{2}\right) \\
& =1-Q(-1) \\
& =Q(1) \\
P_{e} & =\frac{1}{3} Q(1)+\frac{2}{3} Q(1)+\frac{1}{3} Q(1) \\
& =\frac{4}{3} Q(1)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] where, [latex]r=N(4,4)[/latex]

question: Question 36 A full scale sinusoidal signal is applied to a 10-bit ADC. The fundamental signal component in the ADC output has a normalized power of [latex]1 \mathrm{~W}[/latex], and the total noise and distortion normalized power is [latex]10 \mu \mathrm{W}[/latex]. The effective number of bits (rounded off to the nearest integer) of the ADC is  ____
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{S}{N_{q}} & =\frac{1}{10 \times 10^{-6}} \\
\frac{S}{N_{q}} & =10^{5} \\
\left(\frac{S}{N_{a}}\right)_{\mathrm{dB}} & =10 \log _{10} 10^{5} \\
& =50 \mathrm{~dB} \\
1.76+6.02 n & =50 \\
n & =8.01
\end{aligned}
[/latex] rounded off to nearest integer [latex]\rightarrow n \simeq 8[/latex]

question: Question 37 The information bit sequence (11101010 1) is to be transmitted by encoding with Cyclic Redundancy Check 4 (CRC-4) code, for which the generator polynomial is [latex]C(x)=x^{4}+x+1[/latex]. The encoded sequence of bits is ______
solution:
Given information bit sequence [latex]\rightarrow d=111010101[/latex] Generator polymial [latex]\rightarrow C(x)=x^{4}+x+1[/latex] [latex]C=10011[/latex] Generator polynomial having 5 bits, so append [latex]5-1=4[/latex] bits to information sequence. [latex] d=111010101010000 
[/latex] Encoded sequence [latex]=1110101011100[/latex]

question:
Question 38 A continuous time signal [latex]x(t)=2 \cos (8 \pi t+\pi / 3)[/latex] is sampled at a rate of [latex]15 \mathrm{~Hz}[/latex]. The sampled signal [latex]x_{s}(t)[/latex] when passed through an LTI system with impulse response [latex]
h(t)=\left(\frac{\sin 2 \pi t}{\pi t}\right) \cos (38 \pi t-\pi / 2)
[/latex] produces an output [latex]x_{0}(t)[/latex]. The expression for [latex]x_{0}(t)[/latex] is _____
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
x(t) & =2 \cos \left(8 \pi t+\frac{\pi}{3}\right), \quad \omega_{o}=8 \pi \\
f_{s} & =15 \mathrm{~Hz} \\
x(t) \xrightarrow{\text { sample }} x_{S}(t) \xrightarrow{h(t)} & x_{0}(t) \\
\Rightarrow \quad h(t) & =\frac{\sin 2 \pi t}{\pi t} \cos \left(38 \pi t-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Let [latex]p(t)=\frac{\sin 2 \pi t}{\pi t}[/latex] After sampling: [latex]\quad X_{s}(\omega)=f_{s} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} X\left(\omega-n \omega_{s}\right)[/latex] Frequency components present in sampler output [latex]n \omega_{s} \pm \omega_{0}[/latex] [latex]\omega_{o}, \omega_{s}+ \pm \omega_{o}, 2 \omega_{s} \pm \omega_{o}, \ldots[/latex] [latex]8 \pi, 30 \pi \pm 8 \pi, 60 \pi \pm 8 \pi[/latex], .. [latex]8 \pi, 22 \pi, 38 \pi, 52 \mathrm{p}, 68 \pi, \ldots(\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec})[/latex] System will pass '[latex]38 \pi[/latex]' component of input. [latex]
x_{o}(t)=2 \times \frac{f_{s}}{2} \cos \left[38 \pi t+\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right]=15 \cos \left(38 \pi t-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)
[/latex] As per GATE official Answer Key-MTA

question: Question 39 The opamps in the circuit shown are ideal, but have saturation voltages of [latex]\pm 10 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]. Assume that the initial inductor current is [latex]0 \mathrm{~A}[/latex]. The input voltage [latex]\left(V_{i}\right)[/latex] is a triangular signal with peak voltages of [latex]\pm 2 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] and time period of [latex]8 \mu \mathrm{s}[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true?

options.A: [latex]V_{01}[/latex] is delayed by [latex]2 \mu[/latex]s relative to [latex]V_{i}[/latex], and [latex]V_{02}[/latex] is a triangular waveform.
options.B: [latex]V_{01}[/latex] is not delayed relative to [latex]V_{i}[/latex], and [latex]V_{02}[/latex] is a trapezoidal waveform.
options.C: [latex]V_{01}[/latex] is not delayed relative to [latex]V_{i}[/latex], and [latex]V_{02}[/latex] is a triangular waveform.
options.D: [latex]V_{01}[/latex] is delayed by [latex]1 \mu[/latex]s relative to [latex]V_{i}[/latex], and [latex]V_{02}[/latex] is a trapezoidal waveform.

question: Question 40 In the circuit below, the opamp is ideal. If the circuit is to show sustained oscillations, the respective values of [latex]R_{1}[/latex] and the corresponding frequency of oscillation are ______
solution: For given circuit, frequency of oscillations is [latex]f_{o}=\frac{1}{2 \pi R C}[/latex]. For sustained oscillations, minimum gain should be 3 [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad 1+\frac{R_{1}}{R} & =3 \\ R_{1} & =2 R\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 In the circuit shown below, the transistors [latex]M_{1}[/latex] and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] are biased in saturation. Their small signal transconductances are [latex]g_{m 1}[/latex] and [latex]g_{m 2}[/latex] respectively. Neglect body effect, channel length modulation and intrinsic device capacitances. Question 42 Which of the following statements is/are true for a BJT with respect to its DC current gain [latex]\beta[/latex] ?

options.A: Under high-level injection condition in forward active mode, [latex]\beta[/latex] will decrease with increase in the magnitude of collector current.
options.B: Under low-level injection condition in forward active mode, where the current at the emitter-base junction is dominated by recombination-generation process, [latex]\beta[/latex] will decrease with increase in the magnitude of collector current.
options.C: [latex]\beta[/latex] will be lower when the BJT is in saturation region compared to when it is in active region.
options.D: A higher value of [latex]\beta[/latex] will lead To a lower value of the collector-to-emitter breakdown voltage.

question:
Question 43 Consider a system [latex]S[/latex] represented in state space as [latex]
\frac{d x}{d t}=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
0 & -2 \\
1 & -3
\end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right] r, y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
2 & -5
\end{array}\right] x
[/latex] Which of the state space representations given below has/have the same transfer function as that of [latex]S[/latex] ?

options.A: [latex]\frac{d x}{d t}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\ -2 & -3\end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right] r, y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 2\end{array}\right] x[/latex]
options.B: [latex]\frac{d x}{d t}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0 & 1 \\ -2 & -3\end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right] r, y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}0 & 2\end{array}\right] x[/latex]
options.C: [latex]\frac{d x}{d t}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1 & 0 \\ 0 & -2\end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{c}-1 \\ 3\end{array}\right] r, y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 1\end{array}\right] x[/latex]
options.D: [latex]\frac{d x}{d t}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1 & 0 \\ 0 & -2\end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right] r, y=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 2\end{array}\right] x[/latex]

question: Question 44 Let [latex]F_{1}, F_{2}[/latex], and [latex]F_{3}[/latex] be functions of [latex](x, y, z)[/latex]. Suppose that for every given pair of points [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] in space, the line integral [latex]\int_{C}\left(F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y+F_{3} d z\right)[/latex] evaluates to the same value along any path [latex]C[/latex] that starts at [latex]A[/latex] and ends at [latex]B[/latex]. Then which of the following is/are true?
solution:
[latex]\because[/latex] Given integral is independent of contour ' [latex]C[/latex] ' [latex]\int_{C}\left(F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y+F_{3} d z\right)=\int_{C} \bar{F} \cdot \overline{d r}[/latex] is independent of ' [latex]C[/latex] ' Then [latex]\bar{F}[/latex] is conservative field [latex]
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & \bar{F}=\overline{\nabla \phi} \\
\Rightarrow & F_{1}=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}, F_{2}=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y}, F_{3}=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial z}
\end{array}
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Option is true. [latex]\because \bar{F}[/latex] is conservative Then, [latex]
\nabla \times \bar{F}=0
[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad\left|\begin{array}{ccc}i & j & K \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ F_{1} & F_{2} & F_{3}\end{array}\right|=\overrightarrow{0}[/latex] [latex]=i\left(\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial z}\right)-j\left(\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial z}\right)+K\left(\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}\right)=0 \hat{i}+0 \hat{j}+0 \hat{k}[/latex] Equate on both sides, We get, [latex]
\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial z}, \quad \frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial z}, \quad \frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Option is true. If [latex]\bar{F}[/latex] is irrotational then, [latex]
\oint_{C} F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y+F_{3} d z=0
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Option is also true.
But, [latex]
\bar{\nabla} \cdot \bar{F}=\bar{\nabla} \cdot(\bar{\nabla} \phi) \neq 0
[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Option is false.

options.A: There exists a differentiable scalar function [latex]f(x, y, z)[/latex] such that [latex]F_{1}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, F_{2}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}, F_{3}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}[/latex].
options.B: For every closed path [latex]\Gamma[/latex], we have [latex]\oint_{\Gamma}\left(F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y+F_{3} d z\right)=0[/latex]
options.C: [latex]\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial z}=0[/latex].
options.D: [latex]\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial z}, \frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial z}=\frac{\partial F_{3}}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}[/latex]

question: Question 45 Consider the matrix [latex]\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & k \\ 2 & 1\end{array}\right][/latex], where [latex]k[/latex] is a positive real number. Which of the following vectors is/are eigenvector(s) of this matrix?
Question 46 The radian frequency value(s) for which the discrete time sinusoidal signal [latex]x[n]=A[/latex] [latex]\cos (\Omega n+\pi / 3)[/latex] has a period of 40 is/are  _____
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& x[n]=A \cos \left[\Omega n+\frac{\pi}{3}\right] \\
& N=40 \\
& \Omega=\text { ? } \\
& \frac{\Omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{m}{N} \\
& \frac{\Omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{m}{40} \\
& \Omega=m \cdot \frac{2 \pi}{40}=\pi \cdot m(0.05) \\
& \Omega=0.05 \pi \\
& m=1 \quad \Omega=0.05 \pi \\
& m=2 \quad \Omega=0.10 \pi \\
& m=3 \quad \Omega=0.15 \pi \\
& m=4 \quad \Omega=0.20 \pi \\
& m=5 \quad \Omega=0.25 \pi \\
& m=6 \quad \Omega=0.30 \pi \\
& m=7 \quad \Omega=0.35 \pi \\
& m=8 \quad \Omega=0.40 \pi \\
& m=9 \quad \Omega=0.45 \pi
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 47 Let [latex]X(t)=A \cos \left(2 \pi f_{0} t+\theta\right)[/latex] be a random process, where amplitude [latex]A[/latex] and phase [latex]\theta[/latex] are independent of each other, and are uniformly distributed in the intervals [latex][-2,2][/latex] and [latex][0,2 \pi][/latex], respectively. [latex]X(t)[/latex] is fed to an 8-bit uniform mid-rise type quantizer. Given that the autocorrelation of [latex]X(t)[/latex] is [latex]R_{x}(\tau)=\frac{2}{3} \cos \left(2 \pi f_{0} \tau\right)[/latex], the signal to quantization noise ratio (in [latex]\mathrm{dB}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) at the output of the quantizer is ______

Question 48 A lossless transmission line with characteristic impedance [latex]Z_{0}=50 \Omega[/latex] is terminated with an unknown load. The magnitude of the reflection co-efficient is [latex]|\Gamma|=0.6[/latex]. As one moves towards the generator from the load, the maximum value of the input impedance magnitude looking towards the load (in [latex]\Omega[/latex] ) is ______

Question 49 The relationship between any [latex]\mathrm{N}[/latex]-length sequence [latex]x[n][/latex] and its corresponding [latex]\mathrm{N}[/latex]-point discrete Fourier transform [latex]X[k][/latex] is defined as [latex]X[k]=F\{x[n]\}[/latex]. Another sequence [latex]y[n][/latex] is formed as below [latex]y[n]=F\{F\{F\{F\{x[n]\}\}\}\}[/latex] For the sequence [latex]x[n]=\{1,2,1,3\}[/latex], the value of [latex]Y[0][/latex] is _______
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
y[n] & =N^{2} x[n] \\
y[n] & =N^{2} x[n] \\
\left.Y[k]\right|_{K=0} & =\sum_{n=0}^{3} y[n]=\sum_{n=0}^{3} N^{2} x[n] \\
& =N^{2}[x[0]+x[1]+x[2]+x[3]] \\
& =(4)^{2}[1+2+1+3]=16 \times 7=112
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]
y[n]=N^{2} x[n] \quad \because N=4
[/latex]

question: Question 50 For the two port network shown below, the value of the [latex]Y_{21}[/latex] parameter (in Siemens) is _____
solution:
Given two-port network,
[latex]Y_{21}=\left.\frac{I_{2}}{V_{1}}\right|_{V_{2}=0}[/latex] by applying [latex]\mathrm{KVL}[/latex] in the loop, [latex]V_{1}-2 I_{1}-4\left(I_{1}+I_{2}\right)+8 V_{1}=0[/latex] [latex]9 V_{1}-6 I_{1}-4 I_{2}=0[/latex] but [latex]\quad I_{1}=\frac{V_{1}-0}{2} \Rightarrow \frac{V_{1}}{2}=I_{1}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad 9 V_{1}-6\left(\frac{V_{1}}{2}\right)-4 I_{2}=0[/latex] [latex]6 V_{1}=4 I_{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad \frac{I_{2}}{V_{1}}=\frac{6}{4}=\frac{3}{2}=1.5 \mathrm{~S}[/latex]

question: Question 51 Consider a MOS capacitor made with p-type silicon. It has an oxide thickness of [latex]100 \mathrm{~nm}[/latex], a fixed positive oxide charge of [latex]10^{-8} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex] at the oxide-silicon interface, and a metal work function of [latex]4.6 \mathrm{eV}[/latex]. Assume that the relative permittivity of the oxide is 4 and the absolute permittivity of free space is [latex]8.85 \times 10^{-14} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{cm}[/latex]. If the flatband voltage is [latex]0 \mathrm{~V}[/latex], the work function of the [latex]\mathrm{p}[/latex]-type silicon (in [latex]\mathrm{eV}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) is ______
Question 52 In the network shown below, maximum power is to be transferred to the load [latex]R_{L}[/latex] The value of [latex]R_{L}[/latex] (in [latex]\Omega[/latex] ) is _______
solution:
[latex]
I=\frac{V-V_{x}}{2}+\frac{V}{5}=\frac{V}{2}-\frac{V_{x}}{2}+\frac{V}{5}
[/latex] But, [latex]
V_{x}=\frac{V}{5} \times 3
[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad I=\frac{V}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{3 V}{5}+\frac{V}{5}=\frac{V}{2}-\frac{3 V}{10}+\frac{V}{5}[/latex] [latex]I=\frac{5 V-3 V+2 V}{10}=\frac{4 V}{10}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad \frac{V}{I}=\frac{10}{4}=2.5 \Omega[/latex]

question: Question 53 A non-degenerate n-type semiconductor has 5\% neutral dopant atoms. Its Fermi level is located at [latex]0.25 \mathrm{eV}[/latex] below the conduction band [latex]\left(E_{C}\right)[/latex] and the donor energy level [latex]\left(E_{D}\right)[/latex] has a degeneracy of 2. Assuming the thermal voltage to be [latex]20 \mathrm{mV}[/latex]. The difference between [latex]E_{C}[/latex] and [latex]E_{D}[/latex] (in [latex]\mathrm{eV}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) is ______

Question 54 An NMOS transistor operating in the linear region has [latex]I_{D S}[/latex] of [latex]5 \mu \mathrm{A}[/latex] at [latex]V_{D S}[/latex] of [latex]0.1 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]. Keeping [latex]V_{G S}[/latex] constant, the [latex]V_{D S}[/latex] is increased to [latex]1.5 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]. Given that [latex]\mu_{n} C_{o x} \frac{W}{L}=50 \mu \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{V}^{2}[/latex], the transconductance at the new operating point (in [latex]\mu \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{V}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) is ________

Question 55 The photocurrent of a PN junction diode solar cell is [latex]1 \mathrm{~mA}[/latex]. The voltage corresponding to its maximum power point is [latex]0.3 \mathrm{~V}[/latex]. If the thermal voltage is [latex]30 \mathrm{mV}[/latex], the reverse saturation current of the diode (in [latex]\mathrm{nA}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) is ________

Question 56 If '[latex]\rightarrow[/latex]' denotes increasing order of intensity, then the meaning of the words [charm [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] enamor [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] bewitch] is analogous to [bored [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] ________[latex]\rightarrow[/latex] weary]. Which one of the given options is appropriate to fill the blank?

Question 57 P, Q, R, S, and T have launched a new startup. Two of them are siblings. The office of the startup has just three rooms. All of them agree that the siblings should not share the same room. If [latex]S[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] are single children, and the room allocations shown below are acceptable to all, [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|}
\hline \mathrm{PR} & \mathrm{TS} & \mathrm{Q} \\
\hline \mathrm{PQ} & \mathrm{PQ} & \mathrm{RT} \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex] then, which one of the given options is the siblings?
Question 58 Five years ago, the ratio of Aman's age to his father’s age was 1:4, and five years from now, the ratio will be 2:5. What was his father’s age when Aman was born?
solution:
Five year ago Son's age [latex]=x[/latex] Father's age [latex]=4 x[/latex] Five year after [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\text { Son's age } & =x+10 \\
\frac{x+10}{4 x+10} & =\frac{2}{5} \\
5 x+50 & =8 x+20 \\
3 x & =30 \\
x & =10
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Son's age five year ago [latex]=10[/latex] Father's age five year age [latex]=40[/latex] At the time of son's birth father's age [latex]=40-10=30[/latex] year

question:
Question 59 For a real number [latex]x > 1[/latex], [latex]
\frac{1}{\log _{2} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{3} x}+\frac{1}{\log _{4} x}=1
[/latex] The value of [latex]x[/latex] is
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\log _{x}^{2}+\log _{x}^{3}+\log _{x}^{4} & =1 \\
\log _{x}^{24} & =1 \\
x & =24
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 60 The greatest prime factor of [latex]\left(3^{199}-3^{196}\right)[/latex] is
solution:
[latex]
=3^{196}\left(3^{3}-1\right)=3^{196} \times 26=2 \times 3^{196} \times 13
[/latex] Highest prime factors [latex]=13[/latex]

question: Question 61 Sequence the following sentences (P, Q, R, S) in a coherent passage: P: Shifu's student exclaimed, "Why do you run since the bull is an illusion?" Q: Shifu said, "Surely my running away from the bull is also an illusion." R: Shifu once proclaimed that all life is illusion. S: One day, when a bull gave him chase, Shifu began running for his life.

Question 62 Four identical cylindrical chalk-sticks, each of radius [latex]r=0.5 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] and length [latex]l=10 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex]. are bound tightly together using a duct tape as shown in the following figure The width of the duct tape is equal to the length of the chalk-stick. The area (in [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex] ) of the duct tape required to wrap the bundle of chalk-sticks once, is

Question 63 The bar chart shows the data for the percentage of population falling into different
categories based on Body Mass Index (BMI) in 2003 and 2023. Based on the data provided, which one of the following options is INCORRECT?

options.A:
The ratio of the percentage of population falling into overweight category to the
percentage of population falling into normal category has increased in 20 years.
options.B:
The ratio of the percentage of population falling into underweight category to the
percentage of population falling into normal category has decreased in 20 years.
options.C:
The ratio of the percentage of population falling into obese category to the
percentage of population falling into normal category has decreased in 20 years.
options.D: The percentage of population falling into normal category has decreased in 20 years.

Question 65 Two identical sheets A and B. of dimensions [latex]24 \mathrm{~cm} \times 16 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex], can be folded into half using two distinct operations. FO1 or FO2. In FO1. the axis of folding remains parallel to the initial long edge, and in FO2, the axis of folding remains parallel to the initial short edge. If sheet [latex]A[/latex] is folded twice using [latex]F O 1[/latex], and sheet [latex]B[/latex] is folded twice using [latex]F O 2[/latex], the ratio of the perimeters of the final shapes of [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] is
solution: Condition 1: Folding first time Folding first time Condition 2: Folding first time Folding second time Perimeter [latex]=2(16+6)=44 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] Ratio [latex]=56: 44=14: 11[/latex]
